subject: Re: Paper on Abstract vs. Concrete parameters
msgSnippet: ... into a ... achieving ... sometimes by ... http://www.amazon.com/Working-Effectively-Legacy-Robert-Martin/dp/0131177052 ... I didn t read this book and I
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "James Abley" <james.abley@...> wrote:
>
> 2008/8/29 toalexsmail <toalexsmail@...>:
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "kentb" <kentb@> wrote:
> >>
> >> All,
> >>
> >> In spite of the one feedback message I got that my recent post about
> >> abstract vs. concrete parameters was clear, I expanded the idea
into a
> >> paper:
> > www.threeriversinstitute.org/AbstractVsConcreteParameters.html. In
> >> short, it tries to resolve the apparent contradiction between
achieving
> >> testable code sometimes by making parameters concrete and
sometimes by
> >> making parameters abstract. I'd appreciate feedback, examples, and
> >> counter-examples.
> >>
> >> Regards,
> >>
> >> Kent Beck
> >> Three Rivers Institute
> >>
> >
> > I have read your paper and I have some comments. First of all lets
> > consider concrete parameters case.
> > If you have to write unit test to the legacy code you are in trouble.
>
> Have you read Michael Feathers' book [1]? In my experience, a lot of
> people aren't test-infected and there is a lot of legacy code in the
> world, so a lot of people are in exactly that trouble. I find putting
> tests around such code to be the safest way to ensure that I don't
> break anything in unexpected ways when I need to change (someone
> else's, obviously! ;-) ) legacy code.
>
> Cheers,
>
> James
>
> [1]
http://www.amazon.com/Working-Effectively-Legacy-Robert-Martin/dp/0131177052
>

I didn't read this book and I read the annotation and I think it is
valuable one that will contribute a lot for me. Thank you, for
pointing to that book! I will order it and read (not right now, but in
the near future).
